facts.text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated April 12, 1961 of the Bombay High Court.

facts.text: Plaintiff-respondent No. 1 instituted Special Suit No. 5 of 1957 in the Court of the Civil Judge Senior Division at Ahmedabad.

anchor.surface_text: The plaintiff-respondent No. 1 instituted Special Suit No. 5 of 1957 in the Court of the Civil Judge  Senior Division  at Ahmedabad to recover Rs.13,205 on account of the principal lent to defendant No. 7

facts.text: Suit to recover Rs.13,205 on account of principal lent to defendant No. 7 and interest up to date of suit at 9% per annum.

anchor.surface_text: at Ahmedabad to recover Rs.13,205 on account of the principal lent to defendant No. 7 and interest up to the date of the suit at the rate of 9 per annum.

facts.text: On July 18, 1960, claim decreed in sum of Rs. 13,033-6-6 with future interest from date of suit till realization at 4% per annum on Rs. 10,120.

anchor.surface_text: On July 18, 1960, his claim was decreed in a sum of Rs. 13,033-6-6 with future interest from the date of suit till realization at 40 per annum on a sum of Rs. 10, 120.

facts.text: Defendant No. 7 appealed to the High Court against the decree.

anchor.surface_text: Defendant No. 7 appealed to the High Court against the decree. In the memorandum of appeal, defendant No. 7 valued the claim for purposes of jurisdiction and companyrt-fee at Rs. 13,033-6-6

facts.text: In memorandum of appeal, defendant No. 7 valued claim at Rs. 13,033-6-6 for jurisdiction and court-fee.

anchor.surface_text: In the memorandum of appeal, defendant No. 7 valued the claim for purposes of jurisdiction and companyrt-fee at Rs. 13,033-6-6 and his grounds Nos. 1 and 48 of appeal were as follows

facts.text: Grounds Nos. 1 and 48: lower court erred in decreeing suit; decree erroneous, unjust, illegal.

anchor.surface_text: and his grounds Nos. 1 and 48 of appeal were as follows That the lower Court erred in decreeing the plaintiffs suit. That the decree is otherwise erroneous, unjust and illegal and therefore deserves to be set aside.

facts.text: Remaining 46 grounds related to merits of plaintiff's claim, did not deal with correctness of trial court awarding future pendente lite interest.

anchor.surface_text: The remaining 46 grounds related to the merits of the plaintiffs claim and did number deal with the companyrectness of the trial Court awarding future pendente site interest on the rate at which it was to be calculated.

facts.text: Taxing Officer opined appeal against whole decree, subject-matter value Rs. 14,036.80 nP including interest from suit to decree Rs. 1,033.40 nP on Rs. 10,120.

anchor.surface_text: The Taxing Officer was of opinion that the appeal was against the whole decree and that the amount of value of the subject-matter in dispute for purposes of companyrt-fee was Rs. 14,036. 80nP. as the amount of interest from the date of the suit till the date of the decree on Rs. 10,120 came to Rs. 1,033.40 nP.

facts.text: Counsel for defendant-appellant conceded subject-matter of appeal was the decree passed by trial court.

facts.text: Taxing Officer directed payment of deficit court-fee of Rs. 70 and amendment of claim.

anchor.surface_text: He therefore directed the defendant-appellant to pay the deficit companyrt-fee of Rs. 70 on the memorandum of appeal and to amend the claim accordingly.

facts.text: Defendant-appellant filed revision to High Court under s. 52 of the Act.

anchor.surface_text: The defendant-appellant then filed a revision to the High Court under s. 5 2  of the Act. His objection was upheld by the learned Judge

facts.text: High Court judge upheld objection, set aside Taxing Officer's order, held court-fee paid proper.

anchor.surface_text: His objection was upheld by the learned Judge who expressed the view The subject-matter in appeal is the real matter in dispute between the parties and number something which must stand or fall with the decision oil it.

holdings.text: The amount of pendente lite interest decreed is not to be included in the amount or value of the subject-matter in dispute in appeal for the purposes of art. 1 of Schedule 1 of the Bombay Court-fees Act, 1959 unless the appellant specifically challenges the correctness of the decree for the amount of interest pendente lite independently of the claim to set aside that decree.

precedents.citation: Gooroo persad Khoond v. Juggutchunder  1 (8 M.I.A. 166)

anchor.surface_text: Gooroo persad Khoond v. Juggutchunder  1  the Judicial Committee said, in connection with the requirements of the directions in the Order-in-Council of April 10, 1938, with respect to the conditions for granting leave to appeal to the Privy Council, that leave to appeal was to be given in cases where the value of the matter in dispute in the appeal amounted to the specified sum of Rs. 10,000 and that in  1  8 M.I.A. 166.

precedents.cited_proposition: determining such value, the amount of interest decreed up to the date of the decree be included to the amount of the principal
precedents.cited_holding: leave to appeal was to be given in cases where the value of the matter in dispute in the appeal amounted to the specified sum of Rs. 10,000 and that in determining such value, the amount of interest decreed up to the date of the decree be included to the amount of the principal

precedents.citation: Doorga Doss Chowdry v. Ramanauth Chowdry  1 (8 M.I.A. 262)

anchor.surface_text: Doorga Doss Chowdry v. Ramanauth Chowdry  1  is an authority for the proposition that the costs of a suit are not part of the subject-matter in dispute. Their Lordships of the Privy Council said sum claimed, it would be in the power of every litigant, by swelling the costs, to bring any suit up to the appealable value.

precedents.case_name: Doorga Doss Chowdry v Ramanauth Chowdry
precedents.cited_proposition: the costs of a suit are not part of the subject-matter in dispute
precedents.cited_holding: sum claimed, it would be in the power of every litigant, by swelling the costs, to bring any suit up to the appealable value

anchor.surface_text: In Mitthu Lal v. Chameli  1  it was held that no court-fee was to be paid on interest pendente lite granted by the lower Court unless the awarding of it was specifically challenged in appeal. It was said at p. 76 57 All. 71. Interest pendente lite is awarded under section 34 of the Civil Procedure Code.

precedents.cited_proposition: no court-fee was to be paid on interest pendente lite granted by the lower Court unless the awarding of it was specifically challenged in appeal
precedents.cited_holding: Interest pendente lite is awarded under section 34 of the Civil Procedure Code. The Court may award it whether the plaintiff claims it or not. In this respect the Court's power stands on the same footing as its power to award costs to a successful party. It is well-settled rule that no court fee is payable on the amount of costs awarded by a decree appealed from, if no ground is specifically directed against the award of costs

precedents.citation: Keolapati, Mst. v. B.N. Varma I (I.L.R. 12 Luck. 466)

anchor.surface_text: In Keolapati, Mst. v. B.N. Varma I it was held that unless the appellant expressly challenges the award of future interest, no court-fee is to be paid on the amount of interest accruing from the date of the suit till the date of the filing of the appeal.

precedents.case_name: Keolapati Mst v B N Varma
precedents.cited_proposition: unless the appellant expressly challenges the award of future interest, no court-fee is to be paid on the amount of interest accruing from the date of the suit till the date of the filing of the appeal

anchor.surface_text: In Ashutosh v. Satindra Kumar  2  it was said at at p. 382 Costs are not regarded as being any part of a subject- matter in dispute either in the suit or in the appeal. In the appeal, the appellant does not in such an event really dispute the order as to costs for it is the natural order that is ordinarily made following the decision as to the main subject-matter in dispute

precedents.cited_proposition: Costs are not regarded as being any part of a subject-matter in dispute either in the suit or in the appeal
precedents.cited_holding: Costs are not regarded as being any part of a subject- matter in dispute either in the suit or in the appeal. In the appeal, the appellant does not in such an event really dispute the order as to costs for it is the natural order that is ordinarily made following the decision as to the main subject-matter in dispute and if he himself succeeds in the appeal in regard to the main subject-matter, automatically he will expect to succeed with regard to the costs.
